en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceLegalGround: The only legal ground for divorce in England and Wales is if the marriage has broken down irretrievably.
en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceChosenReaso: You had to choose a reason for the breakdown of the marriage (legally known as the 'fact') from the following list.
en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceBehaviourDe: Your {{ case.divorceWho }} has behaved in such a way that you can't reasonably be expected to live with them any more.
en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceAdulteryDes: Your {{ case.divorceWho }} has committed adultery with a member of the opposite sex and you find it intolerable to live with them.
en.whatThisMeansReasonForDivorceSeparatedTw: Your {{ case.divorceWho }} agrees to a divorce and you have been separated for the past 2 years or more.

en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionCourtsOfEngland: The courts of England and Wales must have the jurisdiction (the legal power) to be able to grant a divorce. You confirmed that the legal statement, or statements, given in the application apply to either, or both you and your {{ case.divorceWho }}.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionEachLegalStatme: Each legal statement includes some or all of the following legal connections to England and Wales.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionLivesAreMainlyB: If your lives are mainly based in England or Wales then you're what is legally known as 'habitually resident'.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionIncludeWorking: This may include working, owning property, having children in school, and your main family life taking place in England or Wales.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionExamplesAbove: The examples above aren't a complete list of what makes up habitual residence, and just because some of them apply to you doesn’t mean you’re habitually resident. If you’re not sure, you should get legal advice.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictiondomicileIsUsual: Your domicile is usually the place in which you were born, regard as your permanent home and to which you have the closest ties.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionDomicileComplex: However, domicile can be more complex if you or your parents have moved countries in the past.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionWhenBorn: When you're born, you acquire a domicile of origin. This is usually:
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionCountryYourFath: the country your father considered his permanent home if your parents were married
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionCountryYourMoth: the country your mother considered her permanent home if your parents were unmarried, or your father had died
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionDomicileOfOrigi: If you leave your domicile of origin and settle in another country as an adult, the new country may become your domicile of choice.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionNotSure: If you're not sure about your domicile you should get legal advice.
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionResidualJurisdi: The court may have residual jurisdiction if none of the other connections apply, and both of the following are true:
either the applicant (petitioner) or the respondent is domiciled in England or Wales
neither the applicant nor the respondent is able to apply (on the basis of their nationality or residence) for a divorce in another member state of the EU
In addition, if the marriage is between a same-sex couple, the court may have residual jurisdiction if all the following apply:
the applicant and the respondent married each other in England or Wales
neither the applicant nor the respondent is able to apply for a divorce in any other country

it would be in the interests of justice for the court to consider the application (for example, this may apply if the applicant’s or respondent’s home country doesn’t allow divorce between same-sex couples).
en.whatThisMeansJurisdictionCourtNeedsToKno: The court needs to know if there any other court cases which might affect the jurisdiction of the court, and its decision to grant a divorce.

en.jurisdictionConnectionBothResident: The applicant and respondent are both ‘habitually resident’ in England and Wales.
en.jurisdictionConnectionBothDomiciled: The applicant and respondent are both domiciled in England and Wales.
en.jurisdictionConnectionOneResides: The applicant and respondent were last habitually resident in England and Wales and one of them still resides there.
en.jurisdictionConnectionPetitioner: The applicant is habitually resident in England and Wales and has resided there for at least a year immediately prior to the presentation of the application.
en.jurisdictionConnectionRespondent: The respondent is habitually resident in England and Wales
en.jurisdictionConnectionPetitionerSixMonth: The applicant is domiciled and habitually resident in England and Wales and has resided there for at least six months immediately prior to the application.
en.jurisdictionConnectionOther: The courts of England and Wales have residual jurisdiction, meaning either: no other court in any EU Member State has jurisdiction and either the applicant or respondent is domiciled in England and Wales; or (for same sex couples only) the applicant or respondent married each other in England and Wales, no other court in any EU Member State has jurisdiction, and it would be in the interests of justice for the court to assume jurisdiction in this case.
en.otherCourtCases: Other court cases that could affect jurisdiction
en.onGoingCasesNo: There are no other ongoing, completed or abandoned court cases related to the marriage, property or children.
en.onGoingCasesYes: {{ case.petitionerFirstName }} {{ case.petitionerLastName }} has given the following court cases which are related to the marriage, property or children.
en.whatThisMeansCostOrdersApplicantWasAsked: You were asked if you want the court to order your {{ case.divorceWho }} (and the co-respondent if applicable) to pay some or all of the divorce costs.
en.whatThisMeansCostOrdersFees: This could include all the fees during the divorce, such as the £550 application fee, solicitor fees, and any extra court fees.
en.whatThisMeansFinantialOrdersPropertyMone: You were asked if you want the court to decide how your property, money, pensions and assets will be split.
en.whatThisMeansFinantialOrdersChildren: These decisions are called 'financial orders'. Financial orders can also be made for children.
en.whatThisMeansFinantialOrdersLegalProceed: To formally start legal proceedings, you would need to complete another form (known as Form A) and pay a fee of £255. This means that you don't have to proceed with the financial order at this point.
en.whatThisMeansFinantialOrdersSpltMoney: If you both agree on how to split your money and property and want to make it legally binding, you can apply for a type of financial order called a 'consent order'.
en.whatThisMeansFinantialOrdersConsentOrder: You'll need to get a solicitor to draft the consent order, and then send it to the court with a £50 fee.
en.whatThisMeansFinantialOrdersLegalAdvice: You should get legal advice if you're not sure what to do.
en.whatThisMeansFinantialOrdersCertainCircu: The court can only make financial orders for children under certain circumstances. You'll usually either need to come to an agreement with your {{ case.divorceWho }} (which you can then make legally binding with a consent order) or use the Child Maintenance Service.
en.changeOrAddWarning: If you change or add anything which means the application has to be sent to your {{ case.divorceWho }} again you may have to pay a £95 fee.
